Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 1 of 14
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
 
  )   
CAMPAIGN LEGAL CENTER,  )   
  )   
Plaintiff,  )   
  )   
v.  )  Civil Action No. 18-cv-1187 (TSC) 
)   
  )   
U.S. Department of Justice,  )   
) 
  )   
Defendant.  )   
  )   
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION 
Plaintiff Campaign Legal Center (CLC) has sued the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), 
seeking to compel responses to its February 2, 2018 Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request.  
DOJ has moved for summary judgment (ECF No. 12, Def. MSJ), and CLC has cross-moved for 
summary judgment (ECF No. 15, Pl. MSJ).  For the reasons set forth below, the court will deny 
DOJโs motion for summary judgment and grant CLCโs cross-motion for summary judgment.1 
 
I.  BACKGROUND 
Wilbur Ross became Secretary of the Department of Commerce on February 28, 2017.  
Roughly two months later, he emailed a subordinate, Earl Comstock, stating: โI am mystified why 
nothing have [sic] been done in response to my months old request that we include the citizenship 
question. Why not?โ  (ECF No. 15-5, 5/2/17 Email at 2.)  Ross was referring to his request to add a 
 
1 Due to overlapping facts and claims between this case and another case before this court, 
Campaign Legal Center v. DOJ, No. 18-cv-1771, portions of this opinion are identical to language 
in the summary judgment opinion in that case.  
1 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 2 of 14
question about citizenship status to the 2020 Census Questionnaire.  Comstock replied the same 
day: โI agree Mr. Secretary . . . We need to work with Justice to get them to request that citizenship 
be added back as a census question, and we have the court cases to illustrate that DoJ has a 
legitimate need for the question to be included.  I will arrange a meeting with DoJ staff this week to 
discuss.โ  (5/2/17 Email at 2.)   
Secretary Ross followed up that August: โwhere is the DoJ in their analysis? If they still 
have not come to a conclusion please let me know your contact person and I will call the AG.โ  
(ECF No. 15-6, Pl. Exh. 5 at 2.)  A month later, on Friday September 8, 2017, Comstock sent 
Secretary Ross a memo stating:  
I spoke several times with James McHenry [DOJ] by phone, and after considering 
the  matter  further  James  said  that  Justice  staff  did  not  want  to  raise  the 
question . . . James directed me to Gene Hamilton at the Department of Homeland 
Security.  Gene and I had several phone calls to discuss the matter, and then Gene 
relayed  that  after  discussion  DHS  really  felt  []  it  was  best  handled  by  the 
Department of Justice.  At that point the conversation ceased and I asked James 
Uthmeier [OGC at Commerce] to look into the legal issues and how Commerce 
could add the question to the Census itself. 
 
   (ECF No. 15-7, Pl. Exh. 6, at 2).  The record indicates that Secretary Ross contacted then-
Attorney General Jeff Sessions that same Friday, because the following Monday, Arthur Gary, the 
General Counsel for DOJโs Justice Management Division, emailed John Gore, a Deputy Assistant 
Attorney General: โ[Assistant Attorney General for Administration] Lee Lofthus has asked me to 
reach out to you to find out if you and/or [the Civil Rights Division] have any background 
information regarding some concerns raised that the Secretary of Commerce raised last week with 
the AG relating to the 2020 Census.  I understand the concerns relate to potential questions relating 
to citizenship . . .โ  (ECF No. 19-2, Pl. Exh. A, at 6.)   
The record further suggests that Attorney General Sessions quickly agreed to request the 
citizenship question.  Later that week, Gore connected via email a DOJ employee and a Department 
of Commerce employee to coordinate a call between Sessions and Ross.  (ECF No. 15-8, Pl. Exh. 7, 
2 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 3 of 14
at 2.)  In the correspondence preceding the call, the DOJ employee wrote: โ[f]rom what John [Gore] 
told me, it sounds like we can do whatever you all need us to do and the delay was due to a 
miscommunication.  The AG is eager to assist.โ  (Id.)  A call between Sessions and Ross occurred 
that dayโSeptember 17, 2017.  (Id.)  With the Attorney General on board, the drafting process 
commenced, including the following steps: 
โข  November 1, 2017:  Gore emailed Chris Herren (Voting Section Chief) asking for 
comments and edits on a draft letter.  (Pl. Exh. A at 57.)  
โข  November 3, 2:05 p.m.: Herren responded: โsome comments from me are included in 
the attached.โ  (Id.) 
โข  November 3, 5:10 p.m.: Gore emailed Gary: โthe draft letter that we discussed earlier 
this week is attached. Letโs touch base early next week once youโve had a chance to 
review it.โ  (Id. at 13.) 
โข  November 3, 5:35 p.m.: Bethany Pickett (Civil Rights Division) emailed Gore: โIโve 
attached the letter that we discussed yesterday. I would be happy to discuss this 
further. Please let me know if you have any questions regarding my comments and 
edits.โ  (Id. at 56.) 
โข  November 22: Gary replied to Gore with a revised draft.  (Id. at 14.) 
โข  November 25: Gore replied, writing that he โfound a few nits.โ  (Id. at 17.)  
โข  November 27, 12:43 p.m.: Gore emailed Rachael Tucker and Robert Troester (both 
at DOJ): โAttached please find the near-final draft of the letter to Census.โ  (Id. at 
66.)  
โข  November 27, 1:25 p.m.: Gore emailed Gary: โ[a] couple more nits in the attached.โ  
(Id. at 20.) 
โข  November 30, 4:21 p.m.: Gore emailed Gary: โI have received some nits back from 
the leadership offices, which are reflected in the attached redline and clean versions.โ  
(Id. at 24.) 
โข  December 8, 3:14 p.m.: Tucker emailed Gore: โIโm working to review this quickly. 
Will be back in touch shortly.โ  (Id. at 64.) 
โข  December 8, 3:57 p.m.: Gore emailed Gary: โAttached is a redline of the letter with 
leadershipโs final changes. With these changes, we are authorized to send.โ  (Id. at 
34.)  
 
With the letter complete, Gary mailed and faxed it (the โGary Letterโ) to Dr. Ron Jarmin of 
the U.S. Census Bureau on December 12, 2017.  (Id. at 39.)  In March 2018, Secretary Ross 
announced Commerceโs intention to add the citizenship question, writing that โ[f]ollowing receipt 
3 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 4 of 14
of the DOJ request, I set out to take a hard look at the request and ensure that I considered all facts 
and data relevant to the question . . .โ  (ECF No. 15-2, Pl. Exh. 1, at 2.)    
In June of that year, Secretary Ross clarified, in a supplemental memorandum, that he had 
had the idea before DOJโs request, and that he had in fact asked DOJ to make the request: โmy staff 
and I consulted with Federal government components and inquired whether [DOJ] would support, 
and if so would request, inclusion of a citizenship question as consistent with and useful for 
enforcement of the Voting Rights Act.โ  (ECF No. 15-4, Pl. Exh. 3, at 2.)  This supplemental 
memorandum indicates that not only did Commerce ask DOJ to make the request, it further 
supplied DOJ with the rationale for the request.  (Id.)  By the time Attorney General Sessions 
agreed to make the request, all DOJ had to do was draft and send it.   
On February 1, 2018 CLC submitted a FOIA request to the DOJโs Civil Rights Division 
(CRT) seeking โall records pertaining to Arthur Garyโs December 12, 2017 request to the Census 
Bureau to add a Citizenship question to the 2020 Census Questionnaire.โ  (ECF No. 12-3, FOIA 
Request at 3.)  CLC asked DOJ to search for โ[a]ny documents to, from, or mentioning Dr. Ron 
Jarmin or Dr. Enrique Lamasโ and to use eight search terms: โ2020 Censusโ, โlong formโ, 
โcitizenship questionโ, โquestion regarding citizenshipโ, โACSโ, โAmerican Community Surveyโ, 
โcitizen voting age populationโ, and โCVAP.โ  (Id.) 
DOJ acknowledged receipt on February 9, 2018 and granted the request for expedited 
treatment.  (Id. ยถ 3.)  After conducting an initial search, DOJ denied CLC access to all responsive 
documents on February 28, 2018.  (Id. ยถ 9.)  CLC filed this action on May 21, 2018.  (ECF No. 1.)  
DOJ then conducted an additional search and on September 26, 2018 released 59 pages in full or in 
part, while also withholding 43 pages of responsive documents in full under Exemptions 5 and 6. 
(Cooper Decl. ยถ 11).  On November 19, 2018 DOJ released an additional 11 pages.  (ECF No. 19-1, 
Supp. Cooper Decl. ยถ 12.)   
4 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 5 of 14
At this point, two issues remain.  CLC contests (1) the adequacy of DOJโs search, and (2) 
DOJโs use of Exemption 5 to redact 20 pages and withhold 43 pages. 
 
II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
A.  Summary Judgment 
Summary judgment is proper where the record shows there is no genuine issue of material 
fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a); Celotex Corp. 
v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 322 (1986); Waterhouse v. District of Columbia, 298 F.3d 989, 991 (D.C. 
Cir. 2002).  โA fact is โmaterialโ if a dispute over it might affect the outcome of a suit under 
governing law; factual disputes that are โirrelevant or unnecessaryโ do not affect the summary 
judgment determination.โ  Holcomb v. Powell, 433 F.3d 889, 895 (D.C. Cir. 2006) (quoting 
Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986)).  โAn issue is โgenuineโ if โthe evidence is 
such that a reasonable jury could return a verdict for the nonmoving party.โโ  Holcomb, 433 F.3d at 
895.  Courts must view โthe evidence in the light most favorable to the non-movant[ ] and draw[ ] 
all reasonable inferences accordingly,โ and determine whether a โreasonable jury could reach a 
verdictโ in the non-movantโs favor.  Lopez v. Council on Am.โIslamic Relations Action Network, 
Inc., 826 F.3d 492, 496 (D.C. Cir. 2016).   
B.  FOIA 
FOIA cases are typically decided on motions for summary judgment.  Brayton v. Office of 
the U.S. Trade Rep., 641 F.3d 521, 527 (D.C. Cir. 2011).  โFOIA provides a โstatutory right of 
public access to documents and recordsโ held by federal government agencies.โ  Citizens for 
Responsibility & Ethics in Wash. (CREW) v. U.S. Depโt of Justice, 602 F. Supp. 2d 121, 123 
(D.D.C. 2009) (quoting Pratt v. Webster, 673 F.2d 408, 413 (D.C. Cir. 1982)).  Federal agencies 
must comply with requests and make their records available to the public unless such โinformation 
5 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 6 of 14
is exempted under [one of nine] clearly delineated statutory [exemptions].โ  CREW, 602 F. Supp. 2d 
at 123; see also 5 U.S.C. ยงยง 552(a)โ(b).  Summary judgment for the agency is only appropriate 
when an agency proves that it has fully discharged its FOIA obligations.  Moore v. Aspin, 916 F. 
Supp. 32, 35 (D.D.C. 1996).   
In cases challenging the applicability of certain FOIA exemptions, the district court conducts 
a de novo review of the agencyโs decision to withhold requested documents under any 
of FOIAโs specific exemptions.  See id; 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(B).  The burden is on the agency to 
show that nondisclosed, requested material falls within a stated exemption.  See Petroleum Info. 
Corp. v. U.S. Depโt of Interior, 976 F.2d 1429, 1433 (D.C. Cir. 1992) (citing 5 U.S.C. 
ยง 552(a)(4)(B)).  Agencies may rely on supporting declarations that are reasonably detailed and 
non-conclusory.  See King v. U.S. Depโt of Justice, 830 F.2d 210, 218 (D.C. Cir. 1987) (โaffidavits 
cannot support summary judgment if they are conclusory, merely reciting statutory standards, or if 
they are too vague or sweeping.โ).  The declarations must provide enough information โto afford the 
FOIA requester a meaningful opportunity to contest, and the district court an adequate foundation to 
review, the soundness of the withholding.โ  Id. at 218.  โIf an agencyโs affidavit describes the 
justifications for withholding the information with specific detail, demonstrates that the information 
withheld logically falls within the claimed exemption, and is not contradicted by contrary evidence 
in the record or by evidence of the agencyโs bad faith, then summary judgment is warranted on the 
basis of the affidavit alone.โ  ACLU v. U.S. Depโt of Def., 628 F.3d 612, 619 (D.C. Cir. 2011) 
(citations omitted).  A motion for summary judgment should be granted in favor of the FOIA 
requester, however, where โan agency seeks to protect material which, even on the agencyโs version 
of the facts, falls outside the proffered exemption.โ  Coldiron v. U.S. Depโt of Justice, 310 F. Supp. 
2d 44, 48 (D.D.C. 2004) (quoting Petroleum Info. Corp., 976 F.2d at 1433). 
6 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 7 of 14
In cases where the adequacy of a search is at issue, the agency โmust show beyond material 
doubt [] that it has conducted a search reasonably calculated to uncover all relevant documents.โ  
Weisberg v. U.S. Depโt of Justice, 705 F.2d 1344, 1351 (D.C. Cir. 1983).  The court employs a 
reasonableness test to determine whether an agencyโs search for responsive materials is adequate.  
Rodriguez v. Depโt of Def., 236 F. Supp. 3d 26, 34 (D.D.C. 2017) (citing Campbell v. U.S. Depโt of 
Justice, 164 F.3d 20, 27 (D.C. Cir. 1998)).  โ[T]he adequacy of a FOIA search is generally 
determined not by the fruits of the search, but by the appropriateness of the methods used to carry 
out the search.โ  Iturralde v. Comptroller of the Currency, 315 F.3d 311, 315 (D.C. Cir. 2003).  
However, โevidence that relevant records have not been released may shed light on whether the 
agencyโs search was indeed adequate.โ  Weisberg, 705 F.2d at 1351.  The court must accord agency 
affidavits โa presumption of good faith, which cannot be rebutted by purely speculative claims 
about the existence and discoverability of other documents.โ  Safecard Servs., Inc. v. SEC, 926 F.2d 
1197, 1200 (D.C. Cir. 1991) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).  โIt is well-establishedโ 
however โthat a conclusory affidavit that gives โno detail as to the scope of the examination . . . is 
insufficient as a matter of lawโ in demonstrating the adequacy of the search.โ  Am.-Arab Anti-
Discrimination Comm. v. U.S. Depโt of Homeland Sec., 516 F. Supp. 2d 83, 87 (D.D.C. 2007) 
(quoting Weisberg v. U.S. DOJ, 627 F.2d 365, 370 (D.C. Cir. 1980)). 
 
III.  ANALYSIS 
Although โa motion for summary judgment cannot be โconcededโ for want of opposition,โ 
Winston & Strawn, LLP v. McLean, 843 F.3d 503, 505 (D.C. Cir. 2016), โ[t]his does not mean . . . 
that the Court must assess the legal sufficiency of each and every [claim] invoked by the 
government in a FOIA case.โ  Shapiro v. U.S. Depโt of Justice, 239 F. Supp. 3d 100, 106 n.1 
(D.D.C. 2017).  Instead, 
7 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 8 of 14
[w]here  the  FOIA  requester  responds  to  the  governmentโs  motion  for  summary 
judgment without taking issue with the governmentโs decision to withhold or to redact 
specific documents, the Court can reasonably infer that the FOIA requester does not 
seek those specific records or information and that, as to those records or information, 
there is no case or controversy sufficient to sustain the Courtโs jurisdiction. 
 
Id; see Lujan v. Def. of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992).  Accordingly, the court will address only 
CLCโs arguments in response to DOJโs motion for summary judgment.   
A.  Adequacy of the Search 
Under FOIA, an adequate search is one that is โreasonably calculated to uncover all relevant 
documents.โ  Weisberg, 705 F.2d at 1351; see Oglesby v. Depโt of the Army, 920 F.2d 57, 68 (D.C. 
Cir. 1990) (โ[T]he agency must show that it made a good faith effort to conduct a search for the 
requested records, using methods which can be reasonably expected to produce the information 
requested.โ).  CLC requested โall records pertainingโ to the Gary letter, and as noted above, it 
recommended eight search terms.  (Cooper Decl. ยถ 2.) 
DOJ searched for responsive documents in the Voting Section and at the Office of the 
Assistant Attorney General (OAAG).  (Supp. Cooper Decl. ยถยถ 4, 6.)  Senior staff in the Voting 
Section determined that all responsive records would be found in Chris Herrenโs Outlook account; 
Herren searched his account and located responsive documents.  (Id. ยถ 4.)  At the OAAG, the 
Director of Operational Management determined that Gore โwas the only OAAG employee who 
had a substantive role in the preparation of the Gary letter.โ  (Id. ยถ 7.)  Goreโs Outlook account was 
first searched using the term โcensus,โ and later searched for emails on which Gary and Pickett 
were addressees.  (Id. ยถ 9).   
None of these searches used any of CLCโs eight suggested search terms.  DOJ argues that 
two of the eight terms are too general, but does not address the other six.  (ECF No. 19, Def. Reply 
at 5; Supp. Cooper Decl. ยถ 11.)  This court is mindful that an agency has discretion in how it 
conducts a FOIA search, and that โ[i]n general, a FOIA petitioner cannot dictate the search terms 
8 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 9 of 14
for his or her FOIA request.โ  Bigwood v. U.S. Depโt of Def., 132 F. Supp. 3d 124, 140 (D.D.C. 
2015).  But an agencyโs discretion โis not boundless; the search terms selected must pass muster 
under a standard of reasonableness.โ  Coffey v. Bureau of Land Management, 249 F. Supp. 3d 488, 
498 (D.D.C. 2017) (internal quotes omitted).  DOJโs use of a single search term for all the digital 
records does not pass muster under that standard.  It is likely that responsive digital documents exist 
which do not have the word โcensusโ in them.  Thus, because only one search term was used, and 
that term was inadequate, the search was not โreasonably calculated to uncover all relevant 
documents.โ  Weisberg, 705 F.2d at 1351.  As to this issue, the court will grant summary judgment 
for CLC.  
B.  Exemption 5 
CLC challenges DOJโs invocation of Exemption 5 to redact 20 pages and withhold 43 pages.  
(Pl. MSJ at 18โ26; ECF No. 20 at 9โ14.)  Exemption 5 shields documents that would โnormally 
[be] privileged from discovery in civil litigation against the agency,โ including documents protected 
by the attorney-client, work-product, and deliberative process privileges.  Tax Analysts v. IRS, 117 
F.3d 607, 616 (D.C. Cir. 1997).  To withhold a document under Exemption 5, the โdocument must 
meet two conditions: its source must be a Government agency, and it must fall within the ambit of a 
privilege against discovery under judicial standards that would govern litigation against the agency 
that holds it.โ  Stolt-Nielsen Transp. Grp. Ltd. v. U.S., 534 F.3d 728, 733 (D.C. Cir. 2008) (citations 
and internal quotation marks omitted).  There is no dispute that the first condition is met here; the 
partiesโ dispute is directed to the second condition. 
DOJ argues that the requested materials fall under the deliberative process privilege, which 
protects materials that are โpredecisionalโ and โdeliberative.โ  Mapother v. Depโt of Justice, 3 F.3d 
1533, 1537 (D.C. Cir. 1993).  This case turns on the first requirementโthat the withheld materials 
be predecisional.  Documents are predecisional if they were โprepared in order to assist an agency 
9 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 10 of 14
decisionmaker in arriving at his decision, rather than to support a decision already made.โ  
Petroleum Info. Corp., 976 F.2d at 1434 (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).  Here, the 
contested documents consist of 11 drafts of the letter from Gary to Dr. Ron Jarmin as well as 
redactions from 20 pages of related emails.  (ECF No. 12-2 at ยถ 13.)    
CLC argues that none of the documents are predecisional because they were created after 
Commerce decided to add the citizenship question to the Census and after DOJ decided to issue the 
letter requesting that question.  (Pl. MSJ at 21โ22.)  Defendant does not dispute this timeline, but 
argues that the documents are predecisional because they were created before the letter was 
finalized.  (Def. Reply at 6โ7.)  The parties thus agree on the sequence of events, but disagree about 
what constitutes the relevant agency decision: the decision to write the letter, or the decision about 
the letterโs final contents.   
The inquiry can be circular.  Indeed, every draft postdates the decision to write it, and 
simultaneously predates the decision of what to include in it.  Such is the case here: the drafting 
process postdated Attorney General Sessionโs decision to issue the letter, but undeniably predated 
the decision about the final contents of the letter.  In this regard, Plaintiff and Defendant are both 
right: the disputed materials are predecisional, but they are also postdecisional.  The ultimate 
question is what constitutes the relevant decision for Exemption 5.  
As Wright & Miller have observed, โ[d]efining โdecisionโ for purposes of the privilege is no 
easy task.โ  26A Charles Alan Wright et al., Fed. Practice & Procedure ยง 5680 (1st ed. 1992). 
Though there is no well-established test for identifying the relevant decision, cases in this Circuit do 
provide some guidance.  First, they suggest that the relevant decision in any given case is one that 
involves discretion about what an agency position or agency policy should be.2  The D.C. Circuit 
 
2 This does not mean that a relevant agency decision must involve a formal policy.  See Gold Anti-
Trust Action Comm., Inc. v. Bd. of Governors of the Fed. Reserve Sys., 762 F. Supp. 2d 123, 135-36 
 
10 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 11 of 14
has held, for example, that documents did not fall under Exemption 5 because they โwere not 
suggestions or recommendations as to what agency policy should be.โ  Coastal States Gas Corp. v. 
Depโt of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 868 (D.C. Cir. 1980) (emphasis added).  The Court later elaborated 
on this principle: 
To  fall  within  the  deliberative  process  privilege,  materials  must  bear  on  the 
formulation or exercise of agency policy-oriented judgment . . . [W]hen material 
could not reasonably be said to reveal an agencyโs or officialโs mode of formulating 
or exercising policy-implicating judgment, the deliberative process privilege is 
inapplicable. 
 
 Petroleum Info. Corp., 976 F.2d at 1435 (D.C. Cir. 1992).   
Consistent with this language, this Circuit has held that drafts showing the exercise of 
โagency policy-oriented judgmentโ are in fact predecisional.  See Natโl Assโn of Home Builders v. 
Norton, 309 F.3d 26, 39 (D.C. Cir. 2002).  In Dudman Commcโns Corp. v. Depโt of Air Force, 815 
F.2d 1565, 1565 (D.C. Cir. 1987), the D.C. Circuit withheld a preliminary draft of a historical work 
published by the Air Force about operations in South Vietnam between 1961 and 1964.  The 
drafting process involved decisions about the agencyโs historical conclusions and representations to 
the public.  Id. at 1566.  In Radiation Sterilizers, Inc. v. U.S. Depโt of Energy, No. 90-880, 1991 
U.S. Dist. LEXIS 4669 (D.D.C. Apr. 9, 1991), the Court withheld documents from a drafting 
process that determined what data and conclusions should be included in an interim report to 
Congress about a chemical leak.  Likewise, in Brown v. Dept. of State, 317 F. Supp. 3d 370, 370 
 
(D.D.C. 2011) (โeven if an internal discussion does not lead to the adoption of a specific 
government policy, its protection under Exemption 5 is not foreclosed as long as the document was 
generated as part of a definable decision-making process.โ) (citing Petroleum Info. Corp. v. U.S. 
Depโt of the Interior, 976 F.2d 1429, 1434 (D.C. Cir. 1992).    
11 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 12 of 14
(D.D.C. 2018), the court withheld documents produced in preparation for court filings and for a 
letter to Congress.   
The facts of this case are significantly different.  The letter at issue did not involve discretion 
about an agency position or about the primary reasons for the agency position.  The agencyโs 
position and the reasons for the letter had already been decided.  Thus, the drafting did not 
demonstrate โthe process by which policy is formulated,โ nor could it โreasonably be said to reveal 
an agencyโs or officialโs mode of formulating or exercising policy-implicating judgment.โ  
Petroleum Info. Corp., 976 F.2d at 1434 (D.C. Cir. 1992).   
Moreover, Gary and Gore were not drafting the document so that a supervisor or colleague 
could decide a particular issue.  In Coastal States, the D.C. Circuit held that โa document from a 
subordinate to a superior official is more likely to be predecisional.โ  617 F.2d at 868.  This is 
because such documents generally aid in the decisionmaking process about an agencyโs position.  
Thus, in Access Reports v. Depโt of Justice, the D.C. Circuit upheld withholding a document that a 
low-level employee created for supervisors who had asked for research on a particular issue.  926 
F.2d 1192, 1196-97 (D.C. Cir. 1991).  Such documents are quintessentially predecisionalโthey are 
created to help the agency make a decision.  See Krikorian v. Dept. of State, 984 F.2d 461, 466 
(D.C. Cir. 1993) (withholding a document from subordinates to supervisors that proposed two 
options for how to respond to public inquiries about a recent agency decision regarding a genocide); 
United Am. Fin., Inc. v. Potter, 531 F. Supp. 2d 29, 44 (D.D.C. 2008) (withholding investigative 
notes that were provided to an office to assist it in writing a report to employees about identity theft 
against the agency); Blank Rome LLP v. Depโt of the Air Force, No. 15-cv-1200 (RCL), 2016 U.S. 
12 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 13 of 14
Dist. LEXIS 128209, at *14, *35 (D.D.C. Sept. 20, 2016) (withholding draft documents that 
assisted the Air Force in coming to a decision regarding a settlement proposal).   
Here, the contested documents do not fit that mold.  They were not used to help the agency 
make a decision, but rather were used to communicate the decision.3  If the materials in question 
were drafts of documents that Gore and Gary prepared for Attorney General Sessions before he 
decided to request the citizenship question, they would be squarely predecisional.  But that was not 
their purpose.  While Gore did email the draft to supervisors before it was sent to the Census 
Bureau, it is telling that in the email he wrote that he was sending them a โnear-finalโ draft.  (Def. 
Exh. A at 66.)  In other words, the draft was not provided to supervisors to help them make a 
decision.  The decision had already been made, and the supervisors were reviewing Goreโs 
implementation of it.  (See id.)  
The court is mindful of the D.C. Circuitโs directive that Exemption 5 should be construed 
narrowly.  โIn light of the FOIAโs strong policy in favor of disclosure . . . Exemption 5 is to be 
construed as narrowly as consistent with efficient Government operation.โ  Petroleum Info. Corp., 
976 F.2d at 1434 (internal quotations omitted); see also Wolfe v. Depโt of Health and Human Servs., 
839 F.2d 768, 773 (D.C. Cir 1988).  Consequently, the court finds that the relevant decision for 
purposes of Exemption 5 is the one made by Attorney General Sessions to request the citizenship 
question, not the decision about the final contents of the letter.  The emails sent and the drafts 
 
3 Decisions about how to message agency policy to the public can be predecisional.  See Hooker v. 
HHS, 887 F. Supp. 2d. 40, 40 (D.D.C. 2012) (withholding drafts of a publication about vaccine 
safety);  Hunton & Williams LLP v. U.S. EPA, Civ. A. No. 15-1203, 2018 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 166174 
at *9 (D.D.C. Sept. 27, 2018) (withholding drafts of letters to non-profits and emails discussing 
communications strategy); Sierra Club v. U.S. Depโt of Interior, 384 F. Supp. 2d 1, 20 (D.D.C. 
2004) (withholding documents related to the agencyโs response to a congressional inquiry.)  In fact, 
a court recently held that the contested documents in this case constituted โmessaging.โ  See New 
York v. U.S. Depโt of Commerce, Civ. A. No. 18-2921, 2018 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1772468 at *20 
(S.D.N.Y. Oct. 5, 2018).  These cases are inapplicable here because DOJ concedes that the withheld 
materials are not messaging documents.  (Def. Reply at 15 n.3.)  
13 
 

Case 1:18-cv-01187-TSC   Document 31   Filed 06/01/20   Page 14 of 14
written after that decision are thus not predecisional and cannot be withheld under Exemption 5. 
Because the documents are not predecisional, the court need not decide whether they are 
deliberative.    
IV.  CONCLUSION 
Because DOJโs search was inadequate and the withheld materials are not protected by 
Exemption 5, Defendantโs motion for summary judgment will be DENIED and CLCโs cross-motion 
for summary judgment will be GRANTED.  A corresponding Order will follow shortly. 
Date:  June 1, 2020 
Tanya S. Chutkan                                 
TANYA S. CHUTKAN 
United States District Judge

Case 1:18-cv-01771-TSC   Document 60   Filed 08/19/22   Page 1 of 2
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
 
  )   
CAMPAIGN LEGAL CENTER,  )   
  )   
Plaintiff,  )   
  )   
v.  )  Civil Action No. 18-cv-1771 (TSC) 
)   
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT   )   
OF JUSTICE,  ) 
  )   
Defendant.  ) 
  )   
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION 
Plaintiff Campaign Legal Center (โCLCโ) sued the U.S. Department of Justice (โDOJโ), 
seeking to compel responses to its February 2, 2018, Freedom of Information Act request.  
Specifically, CLC seeks records pertaining to a letter Arthur Gary sent to the Census Bureau on 
December 12, 2017, requesting that it add a Citizenship question to the 2020 Census 
Questionnaire (hereinafter the โGary Letterโ).   
On June 1, 2020, the court partly granted and partly denied each partyโs cross-motion for 
summary judgment.  ECF Nos. 29; 30.  DOJ appealed the portion of the courtโs order pertaining 
to the deliberative privilege process, and in the meantime, the parties submitted renewed cross-
motions for summary judgment.  ECF Nos. 48; 52.   
On May 17, 2022, the D.C. Circuit reversed the courtโs order in part and remanded.  
Campaign Legal Ctr. v. United States Depโt of Just., 34 F.4th 14 (D.C. Cir. 2022).  The Circuit 
found that the process of drafting the Gary Letter to request the addition of a citizenship question 
in a way that protected the DOJโs litigation and policy interests involved the exercise of 
policymaking discretion, and so the letterโs content itself was a relevant final decision for 

Case 1:18-cv-01771-TSC   Document 60   Filed 08/19/22   Page 2 of 2
purposes of FOIAโs deliberative process privilege.  Id. at 18.  The Circuit thus held that DOJ 
properly withheld non-final drafts of the letter, and that most of DOJโs redactions of associated 
emails were lawful.  Id.  The Circuit also found that the record failed to establish whether several 
redacted emails were pre-decisional and deliberative, and remanded for this court to reexamine 
those documents.  Id. at 18โ19. 
The mandate issued on July 11, 2022, ECF No. 57, and on August 7, 2022, the court 
instructed the parties to meet and confer, and file a Joint Status Report setting forth their 
respective positions on the impact of the Circuitโs decision, see Min. Order (Aug. 7, 2022).  The 
court then held a status conference on August 19, 2022, to discuss the partiesโ positions.   
Upon consideration of the Circuitโs decision, the partiesโ respective positions on the 
import of that decision on their pending motions, and for reasons explained at the August 19, 
2022, status conference, the court will DENY WITHOUT PREJUDICE DOJโs Motion for 
Summary Judgment, ECF No. 48, and CLCโs Cross Motion for Summary Judgment, ECF No. 
52.  
The parties shall meet and confer and file a joint proposed briefing schedule for renewed 
cross motions for summary judgment by August 23, 2022, at 5:00 pm.   
 
Date:  August 19, 2022 
 
Tanya S. Chutkan                                 
TANYA S. CHUTKAN 
United States District Judge
